element_texts.text: Completed

Du Quoin
Feb. 1 1863

                                                                                              Du Quoin Perry Co. Illinois
                                                                                              Sabbath P.M. Feb 1 '63

My Dear One 
How troubled do you think I was, and am, when the end of the week came and passed, and I got no letter from home. How I did want to hear from you all. How I conjured up visions of Wilder sick, or Mary sick, or Baby sick; Mother and Nettie worn out tired and sick with taking care of sick children. However I take good heart of hope. Probably you are all well and hearty, and needing me much less than I need you, or at least need to hear from you. And I shall doubt less hear sometime in due Season. I have not failed to write you.
Completed

I write to you the day I left home,
Tuesday from Sandusky,
Wednesday 〜 Chicago
Thursday 〜 Du Quoin
The first you probably get Wednesday the second Friday, and the third you may get Monday or Tuesday. I had nothing to write in them and there was no necessity of writing; only that I was so anxious to hear from you that I could not help writing whenever I could get a chance. Mr Keyes is away at Springfield for I have not yet seen him.  Nor been able to do any thing hardly. Yesterday Mr. Keyes being absent, I paid the Miners $1275.00 for two weeks work. They are paid regularly every two weeks. A good miner can make a dollar per hour in the mine now that they make it a rule that no
Completed

Miner shall work more than five dollars a day; or rather that all over that amount shall get into their common 'Miner's Union fund. 
It is the miners who make the money this winter; but that will bite their own noses off I imagine in the end. I have called round to see the folks some.  Mrs    Keyes in her room at the public house look darker and gloomier than ever. She has not been to Ohio yet, but talks of going in the spring. And says she wants to go to Elyria. 

 Common report speaks of another book - sequel to 'Life among the Angels' that Father Miller has married again in the spirit world, and moreover that the Devil is dead, and that a man from Carbondale below here, now in that region has taken his place.
Completed

I guess Mrs Keyes is crazy - or always was.
Mr Keyes - perhaps naturally does not improve under it. I imagine his health fails. He may not live long.
What will become of Chet?
The celebrated - or notorious Chet Keyes. I guess he is full as well known in this region as his father. I wrote you I believe of his working regularly in the mine - a trapper. - that is a boy to tend the traps or door ways, passage ventilators. Says he is going to mining, as soon as he gets a little stouter.
Mrs. Mitchell has a fine girl baby eight weeks old Bessy Bell by name.
Completed

Today, rose & breakfasted at 9 a.m. immediately to a Sabbath School which I found at the Campbellite Church & about 50. They tried to sing twice, someone tried to pray a little, and for the rest they read over the testament in classes, a verse apiece around that was all.
Then to Presbyterian where I listened to a tolerable discourse on Baptism origins, subjects & obligations. discourse tolerably good, but delivered painfully both to speaker and heaven, on account of some defect in the throat.
This afternoon to Presbyterian S.S. which is a very nice one, under the management of our nice Mr Hatch - the Connecticut Dry Goods Merchant. The S.S. numbers about a hundred, the full of the
Completed

the full of the house. The forenoon audience was about 30 or 40. 
The Sabbath School with 100 scholars and near 20 Teachers, and kept up and made interesting by having a smart superintendent & c.
But children as well as grown people, are more easily interested if not more easily kept interested here than in Elyria.
By the way, Elyria is kind of an old worn out place, do you not think it? Or would it be more proper to say the place is finished? This place is new.
Which is the best kind of a place to live in.
Well the Tea Bell sings.
Please write
Isaac
Completed

Du Quoin
Feb. 2 1863
Du Quoin Perry Co Illinois
Monday Feb. 2 1863
Dear Ones at Home.
Was I not greatly rejoiced to get your letter today noon. It came unusually quick too. Postmarked Saturday 31, reached here the second day after. It must have used the Sabbath pretty full for its journey.
I wish you had written more particularly about the children, Wilder especially. Has Charley's throat been worse since I came away? You wrote of putting Linament on all their throats. I hope the Baby's nose is better by this time. Do you suppose her throat is sore as well as her nose? Write about them.
Completed

Mr. Keyes got home today noon - most sick.
It has been very beautiful weather ever since I have been here until today it is quite cold. Only about 15 above. Zero this morning. Moderating to 20 or higher & a fine snow storm commencing.
Last night I went to the Campbellite Church, and heard a celebrate Roarer - a natural orator - Well he really made the best argument I ever heard for the peculiar idea of the Sect. Let me give it to you Christ rules this world. He is the Savior of Sinners. When he was in the world he exercised his sovereign will, saved whom and as he would. But when he went away he left a law, a rule, a way, by which men could be saved. (This he made out quite skillfully) If he
Completed

made a law, appointed a way, of course that is the way, the only way. What is that way?
And. Believe (of course) and be baptized.
Saul on the way to Damascus, saw the vision - he asked the Lord what he should do. The Lord did not tell him sent him to his servants to whom he had given the commission; Ananias told him 'Be baptized for the remission of Sins.' &c. &c. It seems ridiculous but he did really state it ably.
Well
Please write often
Sincerely
Isaac.
O, I forgot what I began to write for. You mention receiving Keyes letters. Do not say what was in them. Please see if there is any thing I want to know. Take out a Bank
Completed

and send to Lorain Bank for collection.
After all, I do not know if it is collectable without my signature.
You can show it to Dr DeWitt and see what he says
Perhaps it will have to wait for my return.
Isaac
I.S. Metcalf
Completed

Du Quoin
Feb. 5 1863
Du Quoin Perry Co. Ill.
Feb. 5, 1863
Dearest Nettie
Monday I received your letter mailed Jan. 31st and Wednesday I received the one mailed the 29th! Quite a pretty specimen of the irregularities of the mail.
I wrote to you Jan 27th from Sandusky 
-28- Chicago
-29- Du Quoin
Feb. 1st - ~~
-3d- ~~
If I had had any thing to write I think I might have been called a pretty good letter writer.
I have also written to Eliab, and to your Father.
I wrote to your Father that if I should let Herbert have that
Completed

that money, I would still beholden for it. He should retain my note or endorsement.
Honerer Herbert told me before I left home that he did not want it at ten percent which I agreed to pay you know. He thought he could get money at six per cent. But I shall probably have to endorse for him at that. And I presume with my endorsement he can now get money for six percent.
I was a little amused at a bit of note in your letter of 29th which slip of a note by the way I lost out of the envelope on the ground near the Du Quoin P.O. in the dark night - but happened to find again. 
Do you not think that Herbert Brooks had better go to California this Spring?
Completed

Really I do not know but it is. Doubtless he could do very well there with his Uncle.
He would be quite a valuable acquisition to society, social and religious here in DuQuoin if he should come here. Our good people here are quite anxious about it. But so would he be an acquisition anywhere, especially in a new place.
Mine Ettie, fret not thyself about money matters. Trust in the Lord, and verily thou shall be fed. You know I always told you you were to inherit the Earth.
(Only you must help me, as you ever do, to take care that earthly prosperity injure not the prospect of a better inheritance. Perhaps it may be good for us having been poor for a few years thus learning to spend to best advantage.
Completed

We are in comfortable circumstances, Ettie, A very pretty little property in Elyria, part of it a very comfortable - decent at least, place to live, part of it bringing in a little income. 
We have at least five or six thousand dollars at interest, Two thousand of it in U.S. Government Bonds. This above besides this Du Quoin property, in view of which, we must take care to bring up our children so that the inheriting a fortune will not injure them.
As for friends, Ettie they are at the worst, only a necessary evil, (therefore not to be complained of.) Besides few have profited less by friends than we have, and consequently few have better friends than we have. What do you think of that?
Well
Isaac
Completed

Du Quoin
Feb 5 1863
Feb. 5th P.M.
Great Snow Storm & Cold too Egyptians exulting in prospect of fine sleighing.
Your letter of the 3 (mailed 3d) enclosing one from Bangor came to hand. Today. The deed I guess can wait till I get home. The Draft for $100 upon Mr Keyes I wrote you you about. Very like that will have to wait for my signature too.
I am a little anxious about May & the Baby You must write frequently. If they are sick send for the Doctor. I have been afraid all the time of that persistent swelling in May's throat. Do you keep it wrapped in flannel?
Completed

I am afraid Wilder will take cold again, if he goes to school. I would like to hear that the Baby's throat is well. I am afraid that you and Mother will make yourselves sick in taking care of the children. Do be careful both of you.
And write often.
I will write to Wilder I guess.
Sincerely
Isaac
Completed

Du Quoin
Feb. 8 1863
Du Quoin, Illinois
Sabbath Evening
Feb. 8, 1863,
Dear Nettie & Dear Mother
I thought I would turn this sheet over, lest you should think I was at work in the Mine office on the Sabbath Day. I sit in mine own room in exceeding quiet and long to see you both and the dear children too. I did hope to get another letter yesterday, but did not. I am anxious about you all the time, anxious lest the children should be sick, and lest the Mother and Grandmother should make themselves sick watching and caring for them. And here all this week past long, I have been doing nothing, just waiting & loafing, and doing nothing to any account, might just as well have been at
Completed

2
home getting up wood. I imagine it has been good and cold, frozen up, and good sleighing at Elyria. I hope Mr Waldo has got up a good pile of wood. It has been really cold here, one morning 2° below zero of Farinheit. and what is perhaps as strange two days good sleighing. But yesterday & todays the snow has all melted off and the frost is fast thawing out. I may not come home for two or three weeks yet. But I do want to hear from you often.
It has been exceeding muddy & sloppy today, Only 32 at church this morning, but over 100 at S. School afternoon. No meeting this eve. And none at any of the Churches I guess on account of the exceeding dark and mud.
It has been rather a dull day, including a very dull sermon this morning
upside down - letterhead:
Office of the Du Quoin Coal Mining and Manufacturing Company
Du Quoin Ills  1863

The Quality of this Coal has been tested for 5 years and needs no better

recommendation than its use

 Address all orders to B. D. Vandruver, Supt.
Completed

3
Do you remember Mrs Guitteau Nettie, Mrs Fulton's oldest daughter, sister of your little nurse girl. She died yesterday. Her husband is in the Army 1st Lieut Ill. 6th Cav. with Brad. Skinner &c. &c.
They did live in old Du Quoin Village next house to the school house. Afterwards on a farm out north of the Vill.
Your kitchen Pump I think Waldo might have fixed, if he had tried, just take out the Piston & upper valve. I reckon the valve gets turned over somehow. However I hope if not otherwise you have got John Lane to fix it before this time. The man who came to see about that hat stand. I meant to tell you about that. He only needed to look at the place to see what kind of a thing there was room for. I thought he understood it himself. It will only put off the time of having it complete.
upside down - letterhead:
Office of the Du Quoin Coal Mining and Manufacturing Company
Du Quoin Ills  1863

The Quality of this Coal has been tested for 5 years and needs no better

recommendation than its use

 Address all orders to B. D. Vandruver, Supt.
Completed

4
It would not hardly do for us to have an income of five or six thousand a year from Du Quoin Coal, would it? What do you think of it Mother, and Nettie? Would it ruin us all. Well if it was any where else we ought to have. Had we better feel satisfied as it is to get out of it with a whole skin? Or save it to ruin our children? Chance for argument.
Well I want to come home but I do not know yet when I can.
Please take good care of yourselves, and write often
Sincerely
Isaac
IS Metcalf
Completed

Monday Feb. 9 1863
Your letter of the 5th inst. mailed the 6th came to hand today
And as I had not mailed my letter written last night I will write a little more. The letters I have received from you bear postmarks 
Jan. 29
~ 31
Feb. 3
~ 6.
Your letters from home.
I was very glad to have you write so particularly about the children. I presume every thing goes just as well with them as if I were there, perhaps better, and yet I cannot help feeling anxious. I shall want you to write very often & particularly about Little May.
Completed

Very glad that little baby is better I was getting anxious, about her bad breathing and sore nose holding on so long.
Quite an achievement of Charley's getting Gay Pond out of the River, was it not?
Hope you will write often if only a few words, every day if the children are sick. 
My health is first rate but my business not very good.
Great cold snow storm you had Thurs 5th. So had me and cold weather before it too, I am afraid you have not had any good sledding yet per Mr Waldo to get up wood.
Sincerely
I.S. Metcalf
Completed

Isaac Du Quoin
March 17
Du Quoin, March 17 1863
1863
Dearest
Arrived here safely about midnight last night, after quite a comfortable journey. Met Mr Keyes at Centralia on way to Springfield to attend a meeting of Coal Proprietors. Expect him home tomorrow - probably.
Fine weather here - Quite dry and roads good, farming operations progressing considerably.
Coal Business prosperous.
A Draft starting from here a day or two since for me through Chicago probably will reach you in a day
Completed

or two. If coming through Chicago with request for Answer, please reply to it. And hard? it over to Lorain Bank, as you did before. You can endorse it too if necessary

I should like to get home before that School Exhibition if I do not you and Mother must continue to amend it, and report of it to me.
_______________________________________________________________________
Please ask Mr Waldo to go up to my pasture and shut up the gates so as to keep stock out. Morning out if any have got in there. I forgot all about it before I left home
Completed

I will write to the little boys pretty soon.
Please write to me
Please slave not too much.
Take care of your selves, you Nettie & Mother, and get not too tired or work too much.
If you can hear of any body to come to do Sewing at your house please do so.

                   Truly & respectably
                                I.S. Metcalf
Completed

Isaac Indianapolis
March 18 1863
Indianapolis, Indiana
Dear Ones
Have an hour or two to wait here this morning. Have walked round the City till I got tired - seen the State House, Churches, and various public buildings. And sitting down write to you
Mr Jenkins has fixed up some bitters for May. After Dr De La Mater's prescription which Dr Strong thought May had better take. It is an 'Iron tonic' I suppose. You had better get it, and give her some perhaps. He said the dose for an adult was three table spoons full, three times
Completed

per day, before eating. Three teaspoons full would be the dose for a child, Perhaps better not take so much at first.
Here is beautiful pleasant weather, ground thoroughly settled, even dusty, vegetation beginning to come forward Rhubarb, Radishes and Greens in market.
Our Lake Shore has a late disagreeable spring to pay for a fine fall.
Please write to me. If you get out of Flour Hitchcock will send you up a barrell, if you ask him to do it.
And I guess your credit is tolerably good any where
I.S. Metcalf
Completed

March 20th
Mr Keyes did not return last night as expected. So I have not so much to do. Fear it may detain me longer than I want to stay here, if he does not get home pretty soon. I am quite anxious to hear from you and the children. Hope I will get a letter from you today. Have been looking over coal accounts. It is being really a profitable business since Sept. no cost.  Before that it was bad enough.
Balance Sheet Sept 1st to Dec 31 '62 shows balance profits $796,37. Considerable of this goes to permanent improvements, additions to capital stock. And a good deal of it is unsettled accounts, Three or four thousand balance due from R.R. Co. which you know is alway a month or two behind in payment. Two or three thousand  also in accounts against other parties.
Completed

My health is first rate - much improved I think by the change of climate, Beautiful spring weather here as  ..... April day. Like Elyria  .... in May perhaps.
Hope to hear that you have finer weather before this in Ohio.
I mean to be home next week.
Take care of yourselves.
Sincerely 
I. S. Metcalf
Isaac DuQuoin
March 20 '63
Completed

Isaac   Du Quoin
March 21 ' 63

 DuQuoin Illinois
 Saturday March 21 1863

[upside down]Mr. Keyes got home last night.
My dearest
Yours of the 18th mailed the nineteenth came to hand today noon. Very gladly recd of course. Five days I had known nothing about you except by imagination. That is except what I knew before.
The weather here is exceeding fine. There will be no finer weather in Ohio in May , that is has been here ever since I have been here. Ground all nice and dry Gardens looking very finely indeed.
Completed

My new suit of clothes suits me, pleases me much, admirably.
It is beautiful cloth
I wish we had more of it. I ought to have had two pairs of pants instead of one of it. I wrote you two or three times since I left home. I wrote particularly of one thing I forgot before I left. To get Mr Waldo to go up to my pasture, and shut up the gate &c. to keep out and driving out any animals which might trespass  therein,
Much love &c
Isaac
Completed

DuQuoin
March 24 '63
March 24  1863
DuQuoin
Dear Ones
I do not know but I may start home tomorrow or next day, and get there before this letter will. But may not and so write. Great rains Sunday and Monday, after the beautiful weather of last week. But the rain helps to bring forward vegetation. Leaves are coming out, & blossoms too; and grass is considerable.  The Prairies entire are green as grass.
Coal Business is prosperous And is to be - to the benefit of our pockets.
Completed

I have received the first fruits from the new mines  "Tijou & Williams' Walls Colliery" commenced in February, paid over for the first month's rent Feb. 1863  $10.50 My 1/6 = $1.75
Is not that an income.
However they propose to double it every month. March 1863 will be $20.00 at least, and April they expect $40.00 or $50.00 If they keep on so it will amount to something in time.
Moreover the DuQuoin hills which have been mining a little under themselves this winter yesterday paid over Royalty for to March 1 1863 $77.00 My 1/2 of this $38.50
So every foot of coal down under us here is something.
Sincerely
Isaac
Hope a letter today
Completed

Isaac DuQuoin
March 26 1863
DuQuoin Illinois
Thursday Mar 26
1863
My Dearest
I suppose by the time this reaches you, you will have discovered that I shall not get home this week. The Miners are striking this week; I guess they will not strike me to hurt, and propose to stop and see how it comes out. Next Monday will be April 1st, the great striking day throughout the state I expect. Mr. Keyes is not very well, and I will stay and see if I may do any good. I shall probably come home sometime the first or middle of next week.
Completed

Beautiful weather exceedingly, and I enjoy it all the more for getting a nice letter from you today.
Sunday & Monday, After a week of very fine weather, was a great rain. Since then they call it cold. Wed. & Thurs just a little frost, but Bright clear sunshiny days. But the damp & colder weather does not agree with Mr. Reyes I think. His health fails I fear.
All good to you all,
Isaac
My health is extravangtly good especially since I have found a peck of apples
Completed

Camp Cuyohoga
Aug. 27 1863
First Reg
Camp Cuyohoga
Aug. 27 1863
Thursday P.M.
Dearest
Fall business, drill &c, &c. Great labor and confusion in getting things organized in camp for first time. Still every thing goes off very well, our Lorain people, boys are call all here have been very fortunate in quarters &c, &c for which they give me credit some. Probably can not get home Saturday. Anxious to hear from you all. Eliab especially as well as the rest 
Much
I. S. Metcalf
Completed

Camp Cuyohoga
Aug. 31 1863
Camp Cuyohoga
August 31st 1863
My Dearest
I intended to write you a long letter with pen and ink yesterday but did not get at it. We had I suppose a very quiet Sabbath for Camp Life. Inspection at 10 30 A.M. Men with boots blacked & best clothes stand up at their own quarters to be looked at about fifteen minutes. 2 30 P.M. all marched out on Parade Ground at Head Quarters to Divine Service. Band in attendance playing Sacred Music. Hymns set to Dundee Rockingham & Old Hundred
Completed

on printed slips by the thousand distributed among the men. Rev W. N. Goodrich of the First Pres. Church Cleveland officiating. And I almost think I never heard a better sermon, so exactly to the point, so appropriate to the occasion. The only fault I heard found with it was that it was too short, a very curious fault to be found with a sermon by men standing through services. At 5 P.M. Dress Parade which seemed the most doubtful to my conscience. All marched out forming a long double line - most a mile long perhaps standing there while the music marches the whole length of the line. Salute the commanding
Completed

commanding officer. Reading the orders of the day, then Parade dismissed! and all march back again, to their quarters. On the whole I have seen a good many more Sabbaths and in more places. The Militia Officers here are an unusually fine set of men. Of our Company, that is all men officers from our First Regiment of Lorain Co. of which I suppose I am or am to be Colonel there is certainly not a single Copperhead, and apparently not a single bad man: not a single habitually profane swearer. I spoke to my men Sabbath morning requesting they observe the proprieties of the day and it was evident to see how much it pleased them and
Completed

how well they observed it. Even Card playing the almost universal Sunday occupation, was entirely omitted. Excellent letter from you yesterday did me much good. We shall be dismissed, Camp will break up Wednesday P.M. Probably in season for us to get home by afternoon train to Elyria. 6 30 P.M. Sorry Eliab went off want to hear from him. Glad to hear of Cousin Mary B's arrival. Surely I S Metcalf
Completed

Isaac     Albany N.Y.
Oct. 1863
Oct. 22nd  63
Albany, Thurs.
Dearest
We have not got to Boston today as expected. Came on nicely & hastily as far as Schenectady where before 4 oclock this morning we were stopped finding a Freight Train Off Track in the way. And waited there 6 hours before the wreck could be removed & track repaired. So we were too late here for both 5 & 9:30 A.M. Train wait over till 3:30 P.M. However We take it easy  Both had a good nights rest last night. Today have walked the little fellow all around Albany, Statehouse, Court Room &c. &c. &c. State Agriculture & State Natural History Rooms &c. &c. Makes quite a day of sightseeing for him. Instead of getting to Boston before noon, we shall not until Midnight. But Charley can sleep in the cars some.
Completed

We will get to Yarmouth Friday noon & stop there 24 hours I think. I wrote you a hasty note from Rochester last night while Charley slept. I do not know if you may get it. It was mainly because I forgot to tell you that I had changed the Cleveland Paper to Morning Edition So you could send down at noon and get that & mail too.
Whether Charley R or Wilder go down, they had better come home first, so you can send for what ever else you want at same time. Then if you have dinner punctually at 12 M. there is time for any thing. I hope Wilder is better am Anxious to hear. If his tongue is coated or stools white or bad you had better give him tbcum Castor or get Dr De Witt to look at him.
Love & kisses
Isaac S.
Completed

Bangor Oct. 25 '63
Sabbath P.M.
Dearest
I have written a bit to you once or twice during the delays of our journey, but I believe did not write as I intended from Yarmouth  We were hindered 6 hours at Schenectady on acc't of an accident to a Freight Train before us. That made us late at Albany for the Eastern Trains, so we had to wait nearly 6 hours longer there and instead of reaching Boston before noon Tuesday, did not until Midnight  Charley got very tired at Schenectady and Albany, and went to sleep pretty
Completed

pretty soon after we got in the Cars. He slept about all the way to Boston, then went right to Bed at the U.S. Hotel and slept till 6 oclock when we got breakfast and started for Maine, when we arrived (at Yarmouth) at 2 P.M. Charley eat a very hearty breakfast at the U.S. Eat considerable, apples, pop corn &c. &c. in the Cars. At Yarmouth he eat a hearty dinner at 2 and I ought then known better than to let him eat a very hearty supper inc hot biscuit & cake just before going to bed, so it was my fault that the next morning found him crying for home with head ache & stomach ache.
Completed

He was really sick, quite a high fever, and severe stomach ache alas all day. But starvation cure worked admirably: he did not want to and did not eat a single mouth full of any thing solid or liquid, hardly even drink water till sunset and then only a piece of bread as big as his little finger, and today he is as bright as a bird.
They are very well at Yarmouth  George is exceedingly well situated one of the best parishes in the state in all respects. I can tell you all about him and his place when I get home.
Father's health is very poor. Has not been better for 20 years he says.
Fanny I like very much.
I presume they will all be out to see us next year, father & all. if all goes well as now. To tell you all about him & them must be deferred till I get home.
Arrived here at 8 P.M. Eliab, Marie & Mary Elly left here last Monday morning. staid in Boston till Thurs
Completed

Thursday morning, (Same time) I was in Boston, thence to Chester Connecticut where I believe Maria expected to remain while Eliab went to New York.
Charley & I propose to go up to Milo tomorrow. When we shall get back depends somewhat upon Mother. Will write from there
Sincerely  Isaac
Completed

Milo, Oct. 26th  1863
Monday Evening
Dearest
I wrote to you last night from Bangor, a letter which would go today, but if I mail this tonight it will be two days later. Eliab & Maria not being at home, we started this Monday morning by Stage Coach at 6 oclock and came up here. Bitter Cold day froze so hard last night that the ice is not all melted in shady places. Every body complaining of the cold. But we arrived here in good condition this Afternoon. Charley seems well, and quite lively. All we seem to lack now is letters from Nettie, and to know how children & all are. Mother is quite well, got over her cold &c. The rest all well. Little Lucy Eliab's Lucy is here, running with Charles' Anna, and really rosy cheeked Mother says for the first time.
Sincerely,
Isaac
Completed

[Letterhead] KEYES & METCALF'S                                OFFICE OF THE
COAL                                                                          Du Quoin Coal mining & Mfg. Col.
DU QUOIN,                                                              DU QUOIN ILLS.  Dec. 3  1863
ILLINOIS.
Dearest

  I wrote yesterday after I got here, and directed the letter to Wilder, thinking it might encourage him a little. One thing I intended to write yesterday & day before both.

I told Potter the Photographer I would send round to him that other Daguerreotype of Sister Lucy to copy. And I forgot it before I left.
I do not know whether it is at home or at Doctor DeWitt's  Mother knows about it. You can send it by Wilder or Charley Rich.
Note on it, "To be Copied 6 cards"
I want to hear from you Every day, I would like to.
Sincerely

   Isaac
Completed

[Letterhead] KEYES & METCALF'S                                OFFICE OF THE
COAL                                                                          Du Quoin Coal mining & Mfg. Col.
DU QUOIN,                                                              DU QUOIN ILLS.  Dec. 7  1863
ILLINOIS.
Dearest Nettie

 I most always write to you When I am here on the Sabbath Day, whether I do other times or not. Yesterday I did not happen to have any pen or ink. But, Oh how I did want a letter from you. I really expected one Saturday but it did not come.

Yesterday was Episcopalian day. The Presbyterians here preaching but half the time, and the other half An Episcopalian Clergyman from Jonesboro. Mr. Brittain, holds forth. You remember perhaps the three curates in "Shirley". I think this must be one of them, though I am not quite certain.

It seemed almost ridiculous to see the little pompous, rather scanty brained Irishman come in there: (no vestry or dressing room you know) and dress himself in his white robes right before the audience, and then go through with all the minutia of the Service, so almost absurdly. trying to intone in the fashionable high Church style. Well it was almost laughable, and quite tiresome -- to me at least.
Completed

At church there were 40 or 50 for Audience At the Sabbath School at 3 P.M. there were nearer a hundred & fifty - the little Church Crowded full. And Apparently quite interesting. Damon Thing, you perhaps remember him, is very sick, apparently almost to die. Mr. Keyes says he has starved himself to death there six years. "It might be all very well leaving off Tea and Coffee, & all meat. ' if he had eaten any thing else good. But Bran & sawdust alone dont answer."
Dr. Wall has branched out. Times are so good every body so well off he cant get two per cent a month for his money. So he has just put up a brick 3 story block on Main Street. Stores offices I hope you will write to me often. I shall feel bad if I do not get letter today
Sincerely
Isaac
Du Quoin
Dec. 7 1863

Du Quoin
Dec. 10  '63
DuQuoin, Perry Co. Ill.
Thurs Dec. 10  1863
Dear Nettie
Your letter mailed 8th came to hand Today; pretty quick time. I received one day before yesterday mailed 5th.
I am very glad that Baby has got to sleeping in the bed nicely. It must be better for her in winter weather.
Mr. Wilburs Lecture Missionary seems quite an innovation for him. What started it.
Eliab is going to build. I am almost sorry to hear it. It will be a chance if he does not lose upon it. And yet it will doubtless be better for him. to have something to do. He was getting almost quite uneasy for lack thereof.
Completed

People ask when I will return. I hope to get home before Christmas but it is doubtful. I presume every thing will get on just as well in my absense.   School Matters are not serious & can be attended to in my absence just as well. I wish for her sake Cousin Mary could get the place in Grammar School but probably she can not.
Mr Parker has a proposed teacher for that place. Whom I think the Board will want to employ. Mr or and Miss Wheelers money paid on Slip? rents is all right, and my Mem shows it, but I had neglected to copy it upon the Treas. Book
Our DuQuoin Mines again is really prospering nowadays, more perhaps than you are aware of
Completed

Since I was here last spring you know I have paid for that lot of land south of us, next to the Briggs lot  $630.00
H.E. Brook's note                $100.00
Your Father Interest                100,00
Military                                    100.00
Travelling                                 100.00
Your Muff. Teeth, Dresses &c.   100.00
U.S. Bonds                              400.00

                                             $1530.00

Besides usual current expenses.
And - will - have some money left and the prospect of more. Wall's Colliery started last Feb. with an income to me of $1.75 per the month. It has gained slowly and for November pays $9.00 Feb to Nov. Inclusive $56.50
The DuQuoin Mills Mine, one half of the Royalty from which belongs to me pays me about $20.00 for November, or $97.75 Jan to Nov.
Completed

Dearest
Your letter mailed the 5th inst came to hand today, to my great joy. Books promised to lay that floor last week. Write me all about your Sewing Circle. Cousin Mary probably cannot get the Grammar School Place.
I am glad to hear that the Cradle is banished Afraid it made you trouble, hope you have got well over it. I wish Charley had gone to the Dentist when he was at Elyria.
Completed

If the Room is ceiled up all finished, floor laid &c. and the bedstead has not come sent to "Waldeck & Sneares" to see why. Will you have to make bedding especially to fitt the odd shaped bedstead?
Please write often
Sincerely,
Isaac
Written on left edge, sideways:
DuQuoin
Dec  1863
Completed

I believe I have not written about the weather here yet, which of course you always expect. Since I came till Tuesday 8th got all the perfect winter weather of Southern Illinois, no cloud, mild & bright sunny, there can be no finer weather in Greece or Italy: Sometimes just a little frost in the morning sometimes not. Just like the very finest Indian Summer weather in Ohio or East, except that there is a peculiar soft mildness of the air, instead of the kind of crispness east. 8th & 9th Cloudy & a little rain. But the very rains here seems if not dry, at least soft & mild, compared with the sharp chilly harsh cloudy weather elsewhere.
Completed

Some anxiety here now about the 6th Ill. Cavalry, in which Brad Skinker Capt. commands one Company from this place.
The Regiment is reported badly cut up at Lagrange the other day in a Guerrilla fight. But no particulars yet received.
It was Col. Loomis of DuQuoin Col of that Regiment, who was shot a few months ago by a drunken Major Harrod of Shawneetown, of the same Regmt Capt. Skinner came home with the body. Widow & 4 little girls here in DuQuoin.
Sincerely
Isaac
written upside down:
DuQuoin
Dec. 1863
Completed

Sabbath Dec. 13th 1863
DuQuoin Perry Co. Illinois
I believe I have not written anything about the weather lately  The first week I was here, it was the most beautiful of beautiful Egyptian weather all the clear mild cloudless days, day after day alike. Monday Night 7th it clouded up at night and rained on the night. And it has not cleared off yet! There has been little rain till today, but constant mild warm cloudy weather. Very comfortable weather, here you know we do not have much mud - have dirt instead - the sheets are made of coal slack, all sidewalks are of this material, which is perhaps as good as any gravel. But there is a blackness to it, and an imperceptible shade thereof will follow the feet on to the carpets &c.
This forenoon at the Presbyterian Church Old Mr Stafford preached to about 15 persons. If it does not clear off I do not know what the audience will be this evening. It really rained very hard awhile this morning
Completed

I have only got two letters from you since I left home, How many I have written I can hardly tell. Yours were mailed the 5th & 8th. I hope to get another tomorrow.
How much longer I shall remain here I cannot tell. I mean to try to get home by Christmas but may not. There is much to attend to and I ought to spend more of my time here. But the fact is, especially of late years that I do sort of like to stay at home, certainly when my wife and children happen to be there.
Had not we better move out here Nettie? There is really a great need of "dacent people" here. There is for a new RR Town a very fine proportion of such. But as every where else they need strengthening. The Mines bring in a great understratum of the very worst. They have got so strong here just now as to govern, I hope it will not continue. Liquor selling is regularly licensed, and prevails enormously
Completed

DuQuoin
Dec. 16  '63
DuQuoin Dec. 16  1863
My Dear
I must tell you of the Riot here yesterday. The DuQuoin Mining Journal Office was cleaned out by a party of soldiers.
I have been almost anticipating something of the kind ever since I have been here. Government Trains of Soldiers you know are passing here almost every day. Last week I know a Cavalry Regiment from Indiana talked of it. Yesterday a fine battery of Artillery, 10 cars of horses 6 cars of brass guns & carriages, 4 cars of Baggage & 3 cars of Soldiers, happened to be stretched out here
Completed

and waiting an hour or two for other trains.
Some resident I suppose told some of the soldiers there was a copperhead newspaper published here. So in the absence of their officers, who were gone round to the bakery to look out for rations, a party of the soldiers started for the office. The building you know belongs to Mr Keyes, is on the same block with his house & uptown office. And next the Monk House. The soldier boys rushed in drove out or threw out the printers tipped over the forms, threw the type into "pe" and out the windows breaking glass sash and all, tipped over the stove of burning coal onto the floor seized upon the half printed newspaper of the week & carried
Completed

off for distribution among their comrades.
Mr Keyes got round there in time to pick up the coal and save the building from burning up. So the damage to him, was only the windows &c. To the printer some two or three hundred dollars perhaps.
All well.
Hope you are so.
Colder weather
A little snow
Truly
Isaac
Completed

DuQuoin
Dec. 15 1863
DuQuoin  Perry Co. Ill.
Tuesday Dec. 15  '63
My Dearest
Just came to hand your nice letter, mailed the 12th; and also one from your Father mailed the 9th.
I wish the children did not have colds so; but I do not know how to help it.
Does Charley Rich keep water in the evaporating pan in the furnace? Do you keep abundant ventilation in your sleeping rooms by night: Do your Children be washed all over in cold water every day? That makes the difference with me.
Completed

Do they get their feet wet in going out doors, and stay with them wet and cold long times?
I guess Charley Rich had not better dry up the cow as long as she gives a good mess of milk and you want to use the milk; but he must try especially and not let her grow poor, for I shall want to kill her by and by. If it is cold & stormy the young cattle must be brought back from pasture.
One thing I forgot to dig my chicory roots If there is any pleasant weather Charley Rich had better dig them perhaps and was the Roots.
Completed

The letter from you today was the third one I have got.
I am very well and comfortable.
I expect now to get home sometime next week.
Sincerely
Isaac.
Completed

Elyria Feb. 25th 1864
Thurs. 6 P.M.
Dearest
Children all nice & well. Charley, I guess has got over his trouble, though he claims that he cried once today because he was lonesome. I write this to advise you to remain till Saturday. I do not want to see you out here before Saturday night if you can find any place to stay. So take plenty of time to see and hear every thing you want.
Written up the left side:
Dr DeWitt arrived home safely tonight
Completed

Do not be in a hurry, and do not get tired yourself. The Museum in the Court House is quite an attraction, but it takes near two hours to get through it in the crowd. The Paintings also in Court House is also good, though the collection is not yet catalogued. Next week would be better time for most all the show. Mechanic Hall will hardly be fairly open at all this week. However it is perhaps worth going through now, just to see a machine that pegs a foot or shoe in about half a minute. Make the pegs too as it goes along. That machine it is said has pegged two hundred thousand prs of boots.
Completed

Do not neglect to go and see the "Stereoopticen" at the Cleveland Music Hall Bank St. just North of Weddell House next door to Angier House. Every day at 2 & 8 P.M. They say Baby has not cried at all today. Do not worry about Mrs Root's money or Mrs Wooster's Muff. I guess you will not lose yours. Especially Isaac
Completed

Isaac
Feb. 25 1865
Ohio
Galion, Crawford Co
Tues. P.M. Feb. 21 1865
Dearest
Here I am, behind time, and delayed here 12 or 14 hours. Dull place. Slightly vexatious. So instead of reaching DuQuoin tomorrow noon, it will be some time in the night -- that is, if  I do not get stopped again. Take Care of yourself and not get tired and do too much
Great news this morning of Sherman's occupation of Charleston, which you hear before this reaches you.  I am very sorry to come away from home and leave Eliab there -- and it vexes me all the more to be detained here.
Any thing you want or need from store
Completed

or any thing you can get Charles to attend to. We will be there most every day. And do not be slow to call upon Josey for to do any thing you want done.

 You had better ask Charley or Josey or both to come around Sabbath Morning and carry those Question Books.

Miss Wheeler -- Nettie -- will distribute the papers if you send them to her.
If the Monthly paper - "Childs Paper", or "Child at Home" should come this week, better throw them in the drawer and let them wait till I get home.
Please write to me, as often as convenient - every day if you can, if only half a page but only this week, or not after Sunday, Monday Morning lays
Completed

I may get home before the end of next week.
I wish Eliab could wait till I get home.
If the Children are not well or any thing is the Matter Telegraph.

 Take especial care of yourself - you know you have no one while I am away to scold at you for sewing or any thing.
 Love etc.
               I.S. Metcalf
Completed

Oh have you heard anything of the new scheme, the Travellers Insurance?
At Every Depot this Winter they sell Travellers Insurance Policies. Life Insurance against all accidents in Travelling for ten cents per day per $3000.00
Every body buys a policy as they buy their R.R. Tickets.
My insurance for two days how ever did not save my being left here 14 hours.
Completed

Isaac 
Feb 22 1865

                                                                           Mattoon Illinois
                                                                             Wed Eve. Feb, 22d 1865

Dearest Nettie

 Here I am stopped again till tomorrow morning.

The RailRoads in this country seem to have left off trying to make any connections. Entirely overrun with Passengers & freight, more business by far for their rolling stock can do, they seem to have given up trying. I thought it was bad enough last year. It has grown no better very fast.
I left Galion Ohio at 2 A.M. very comfortable in sleeping car till Noon at Indianapolis. Since then every car crowded, not merely every seat, but the aisles between the seat all all crowded full - all the time.
Completed

Arrive here at Mattoon at 7 P.M. Train for the south passed here about 5 P.M. Next Train at 6 A.M. Tomorrow. Worse than all that the Chances for a bed very slim indeed. Probably twice as many people in the house as there are beds for. However I always make out somehow. Pretty apt to get a chance if any one does. If I do not get stopped any where else I shall get to Du Quoin tomorrow noon 24 hours behind time.
I have thought for a year or two that there were a great many people out west: but I never realized it I think quite so fully as today.
Completed

I wrote to you from Galion where I made my first detention yesterday of nearly 14 hours. and have nothing particular to unite tonight, only to tell you of my delays, and to request you to take good care of my wife & children,
If Eliab had come with me I guess he might have thought the west a hard road to travel.

 I do not like it very well to come away and leave him. I hope you will write to me frequently - every day, - this week. I shall be anxious to hear how the Children get along etc. etc.
                     Absolutely yrs
                                    I.S. Metcalf
Completed

[Letterhead] KEYES & METCALF'S                                OFFICE OF THE
COAL                                                                          Du Quoin Coal mining & Mfg. Col.
DU QUOIN, Ill.                                                         DU QUOIN ILLS.  Feb. 23 1865
My Dearest

 Arrived here in good order and conditions about one oclock this Afternoon, seven hours from Mattoon, and just twenty four hours longer from home than I expected: waiting thirteen hours at Galion,  Ohio, and eleven hours at Mattoon Ill.

Mr. Keyes not in town today. He lives you know five or six miles out of Town nowadays. You remember he and Mr. Mead wrote about it last summer. He is usually here every day, but yesterday & today could not get here by reason of high water, from a great rain Tuesday Night. The great reason for his moving out of Town, as far as I can learn was to get Chetty away. He was getting wild and rude beyond control they say. Bad enough when I was here last, and grew worse considerably. After he was brought home drunk once or twice, and a great flogging
Completed

Isaac Feb. 23 1865
flogging perhaps the first he ever had) did not do any good, he thought best to get him away out of the village as soon as possible I guess. So he lives off there five or six miles from here, four or give from the Old Town, and I do not know but he will build up another village there - of refuges and freedmen.

 General time of health here, every body well and hearty. Milford Hinkley moved his family up here, bought out Col. Campbell. Our Frank Campbell, used to run our Mines you know.

And Col Campbell rents his place at old Town.
Milford Hinkley of course makes money, and so do the Smiths. Brad Skinner is still in the Army. his three years is out some time since, but they hold him in service three years from date of his Commission as Captain of Cavalry.
Mrs. Root I have not seen but understand that she is quite smart and healthy.
I am anxious to hear how you all are at home
Completed

[upper right-hand side]Isaac  
Feb. 25, 1865                                                                                   Du Quoin Perry Co. Illinois

                                                                                                           Saturday Eve. Feb. 25 1865

My Dearest Nettie

                             I was quite disappointed today at not receiving a letter from you. I hoped a little yesterday. Today I quite relied upon it but it did not come.
Well I still hope for better luck Monday, and console myself by thinking that if any thing had been the matter of yourself or children you would have written early enough so I could have received it this week.
I have been pretty busy here in Office ever since I came here, and expect to be while I stay. Could be if I had several times as long to stay.

Mr. Keyes comes up every day no matter what the weather is. Now a days it is really quite an under taking 5 or 6 Miles of Illinois Mud roads. Two creeks to cross - by fording. Nearly swimming they are too now. One or two days this week they were so. Last night was another great rain Mr. Keyes came up this morning before Six Mile Creek got up. To night it is undoubtedly swimming deep, but he went back just at night saying he could turn his horse out on the side and there was a big tree fallen high across the stream that he could cross in.
Mr. Keyes' health appears very good, he has had no cold or cough all winter, and I think looks stronger than I ever saw him.

He eats but twice a day ever nowadays. Comes up here in the Morning, and eats nothing till he gets home at night.

I hardly know whether I shall get down there or not. I have not much time to spare certainly.
Completed

This evening I called around and had a long talk with Aunt Sally, - Mrs. Root. 
She is very well this winter, apparently better than usual for some years, and just as happy as ever she was.
It was enough to do anyone - a christian at least, good, to hear her talk of Anna, and of her death. 
She did not mourn at Anna's death, rather rejoiced - could have shouted with joy when she died, or as she lay dead in the house. Her very coffin, and her grave more a joy and a pleasure to her. She was a joy and a pleasure to her while she lived, and she had been ever since.
By the way, some one ought to write Aunt Sally's life. You know she was with her husband, first pioneer in all this region. He came out her[e] to establish a ferry on Muddy river, on the old great Shawne[e]town & Kaskaskia Trail. That was in 1819. There was no St. Louis then you know hardly .  The old French town of Kaskaskia was the end of the world in this direction as it were. and its outlet was through here to the Ohio River at Shawneetown. The nearest white family or person was 12 miles either way to the ferries on the next rivers.
She said last night she had lived night after night by the week entirely alone, no other human being within twelve miles; and why should she be afraid to stay alone in her house now with kind neighbors within call on either side. She had no patience nowadays with folks that complained of hardship and disagreeables of living in this country. 
I mean to get home Friday or Saturday next though I expect I shall have to go by way of Chicago which will take a little longer.
I hope to get a letter from you Monday.
Sincerely
Isaac
Completed

KEYES & METCALF'S                        OFFICE. 
COAL                                             Du Quoin Coal Mining Company. 
Du Quoin, Ill.                                    Du Quoin, Ill., Feb. 7 1866
My Dearest

I arrived here in good health & condition last night, or rather this morning between two and three; Had a tolerable nights rest before nine o clock, and ready for business. Mr. Keyes is away at St. Louis, but will be back in a day or two. Things are going on about as usual here. Continued growth & improvement of course more & more brick buildings etc. Keyes still live down in the woods, & Mrs. Keyes they say has not been up to Town for Months. The propose to build a great school house here this season, cost twice as much probably as our Elyria School House did, though everything costs twice as much now as then. Make Taxes amount to something. Taxes have been very light heretofore here. For two years to come the School House tax alone in this burgh will be much more than all our tax in Elyria.

I hope you wrote to me yesterday & day before, and
Completed

again today for I am of course anxious to hear all about the children and all. Can but feel anxious about the children till after time for baby & Anna to have Measles if they have been exposed. I think I shall be home next week. Perhaps you had better not write to me after this reaches you, without it reaches you soon or rapidly.
I think now I shall return via Chicago.
If any thing happens to trouble you you can telegraph.   Sincerely

                                                                                             Isaac S.

[right-hand bottom corner] Isaac

                                         Feb. 7, 1866
                                        Du Quoin
Completed

[Illustrated Letterhead]
KEYES & METCALF'S                        OFFICE. 
COAL                                             Du Quoin Coal Mining Company. 
Du Quoin, Ill.                                    Du Quoin, Ill., Feb 11 1866
[upper left corner] Isaac. Feb 11

                           Du Quoin /66

Nettie Dearest

                        Your letter of Monday last came safe to hand Saturday. Written the day I left, mailed the next morning. I stopped one day on the way, and got here Wednesday, Morning at 2 a.m. before light: the letter Saturday morning at 8 A.M. Such are Uncle Sam's Mails. I am doing well here, getting along well that is. Mr. Keyes got home Friday P.M.

I mean to get home by next Saturday but cannot tell for certain.  Heard a Temperance Sermon this forenoon, this afternoon have been to S.S. 
Saw B.G. Roots today. Mrs. Roots you know died a year ago or more. He had married again with in a few weeks. You cannot guess who. I would wait and let you guess, if I were not afraid it would hurt you.
You remember Miss Paine & Miss Reynolds. Miss Weeks by the way has just come back to the Old Town Seminary, which drags on a very slight and precarious existence.
Completed

Miss Reynolds you remember married a venerable old gentleman named Saunders. Widow Saunders has lately married B.G. Roots
Philander Keep is at Pikes' Peak (Nevada) 
Logan Holt is an Army Commissary in Miss. perhaps.
Dined today at Milfrod Hinkley's. They live in very fine style in the house Colonel Campbell built.
Supper Bell

                                  Sincerely
                                         I.S. Metcalf
Completed

Indianapolis In.
Feb. 6 12 M.
Intended Dearest Nettie to write you on yesterday but did not get time. Wrote to Charles instead I took tea at H.E. Brooks' , and left Cleveland by night train at 9.30 P.M.
Sleeping Car at Galien about 2 PM 
Slept till about 10 this forenoon
Just arrived here near two hours behind time. Go in in half an hour.
Hope you are all doing well. Have the boys take good care of Cow & pig.
And write to me
Expect to get to DuQuoin before tomorrow morning, if not delayed too long at Mattoon

                                                                                                                           Isaac
Completed

[upper left corner] Isaac Feb. 14, 1866                                                Illinois Central Rail Road Co.
Du Quoin                                                                                                 DIVISION SUPERINTENDENT'S OFFICE.

                                                                                                          Centralia, Feb. 14, 1866

Dearest Nettie

              When shall I get home? Doubtful, I guess. Present appearances are against it decidedly. I tried to leave DuQuoin this Morning at 6 A.M. But on account of a Freight Train off the Track toward Cairo, the Train did not come till 4 P.M. When I came along as far as here. Meanwhile it had turned excessively cold. No snow at all at DuQuoin, and not freezing any till Morning. Here all frozen up, and from here to Chicago, all trains snowed up and frozen up, very little prospect of any train over the road tomorrow or perhaps for longer. I do not know but I shall decide to go back to DuQuoin tomorrow and stay over Sabbath.
Completed

If I do go back I will Mail this so that you may know (if this gets through via Cincinnati) what has become of me.
I have contracted to go via Chicago

                                                                  Respectfully
                                                                   And much more too
                                                                                           I.S. Metcalf

Isaac St. Louis
May 17, 1866

                                                                     St. Louis May 17 1866

Dearest

 I wrote a note to you yesterday stating merely the fact of my arrival here etc.

I got pleasant acquaintance of sundry "commissioners", both Old & New School on the way here; among the rest the Rev. Mr. Richards whom you heard preach last Sabbath and an ancient Elder of his Church in Deleware Co. N.Y. who probably never was out of his ancestral "neck of the woods" before. I notice he sticks close to Mr. Richards Coattail. I find here Rev. Mr. Post formerly of DuQuoin of whom you have heard me speak. The DuQuoin Minister who went into the Army, and who now is a Missionary on the
Completed

Iron Mountain R.R.d down which I talk of making an excursion to see our R.G. Kerr late of Elyria now superintendent of a Lead Mine 50 Miles fm St. Louis.
Mr. Post you know lost his wife at Du Quoin & married again that little Ross girl whom you doubtless remember went to school there, perhaps was in your S.S. Class, sister of Ellen Walls' husband?
Old Father Gibson is here too, (whom you doubtless remember) as large as life and with the same old "Jolly Red Nose". Also Dr. Storer of Carbondale, whom you do not remember. And by the way also Old Dr. Beman formerly of Troy N.Y., who now you know lives at Carbondale, south of DuQuoin of late yrs.

 I have a very good boarding place at a Mr. Morse's 123 Chouteau Av.
Completed

There has been no warm weather since we came hither. Indeed there are bitter complains of the cold. But the season is very much in advance of Northern Ohio. This of course. Vegetation here now is that of the last of June almost with us in Ohio. We had on Dinner Table Asparagus, beets, onions, radishes, head lettuce, and desert of abundant Strawberries. Garden here are about a full month later.

I am anxious to hear how you are getting along, how the boys do etc. etc. I ought to have told you something about writing before I left and I am afraid you will not think of it, or will not write till you hear from me which will make it some time before I shall hear any thing from you
Completed

Ten or fifteen years ago, when I used to be in St. Louis, it was evidently and distinctively a Southern City; every thing had the distinctive Southern look, with perhaps an especial dash of northern bustle. But now the City is as distinctively Northern in almost every aspect. The Draymen and teamsters who used to sit on their horses, now ride their Drays etc. And other thing in proportion especially as to the Colored people And the City too is improving now, almost or quite equal to Chicago. It is surprising to Change
Completed

about a mile nearly, very pleasant walk from Church. Excellent Methodist People, Northern & Union, sorry would not take Old School for fear they might not be union.
Assembly opened today by op? with an most excellent sermon frm Rev. Dr. Jas. B. Shaw of Rochester N.Y. "O Thou that hearest Prayer" The Assembly is as most solemn & dignified body at least it moves as slow as -- mule power. A.M. simply heard the Sermon  P.M. Elected a Moderator, and talked for two hours over sundry unimportant points of order & procedence
Completed

Moderator Elect is the very Rev. Dr. Hopkins of Auburn Theol Sem. tall & dignified, but evidently not knowing very well how to preside over so excessively awkward a body as a collection of Ministers, I presume there are lots of laymen here who could preside over a body of business men and do more business in two days than this will do in two weeks. I know J.P. Handy of Cleveland who is here with John Monteith could.
Well I will write frequently.
Write to me. Write
Care of To. Gen. Ass. I.S. St. Louis
Completed

Isaac St. Louis
                                                                                                      May 21. 1866
                                                       St. Louis May 21st 1866

Dearest

I wrote to you I believe every day last week; and am getting anxious to hear from you, and know how the Children & all get along in my absence. Saturday night was the "Elder's Meeting." It was a little curious to see how anxious how many were have their own voice heard in relation to their experience in ruling the church. So they adjourned to try it again some other evening.

Yesterday morning I visited two Sabbath Schools, and heard Rev. Dr. McCosh, an old Scotch Irishman, greatly distinguished as an author theological & metaphysical. In the Afternoon I went to the celebrated St. Louis "South Mission S.S.", which was started and superintended by Gen Fisk as long as he staid in St. Louis. The school now number 1700 or more. It is decidedly
Completed

decidedly an institution of itself. Building built on purpose for it, and everything fitted for it.
In the evening I went to Dr. Post's Church, - the Congregational Church; and heard Dr. Hatfield of New York.

The great interest here as all over the country attaches to the Old School Assembly. They have had now about all the time so far a great discussion of National interest, as to what shall be done with certain secessionist Kentuckians upheld by certain Missionaries of the same stripe who have refused to submit to the antislavery & patriotic deliverance of the previous Gen. Assembly.
The Matter is not yet decided, and may occupy all this week for aught I know. If the Old School should finally purge itself of this Southern it would I suppose remove the great obstacle to what many of both sides are figuring for, a ReUnion of the N.S. & O.S.
Completed

Isaac St. Louis
                                                                                                    Monday May 21 '66

Dearest Nettie
I have to keep writing not yet hearing from you. To day in our Assembly has been the reception & speech of Dr. Harper a representative of the United Presbyterians. The receptions etc. of Dr. McCosh the great Scotch Irish Presbyterian. The report of a Committee on Foreign Missions with a speech from Sec.ry Wood of Am Board And a report of Committee on Church Extension with a new plan of procedure, and a great and greatly mixed up discussion thereon.
I went into the Old School Assembly a little while today. There is where the great the national interest is nowadays. There were crowds of rebel sympathizers there today, and some great speaking which I must tell you of sometimes.
Besides I went to a Photographs Saloon. A leading Photographer of the City request the members of Assembly to sit Each for their picture, sit separately & then he will group them in a great picture I reckon.
Often to fix up a dozen Cartes de visite for Each gratis to pay for the trouble of sitting
Thursday 24 the whole Assembly are invited to visit the Iron Mountain 7 am. to 9 P.M. The grand Trip by rail
Completed

ISM
St. Louis May 26 1866                                                                                   May 22d 1866.

                                                                                                                     St Louis Mo.

Very Dearest

Your letter the first of 16th 17th came to hand this morning to my great joy. I shall hope now to hear from you very often. I calculate to write mostly every day myself. I have so far except the Sabbath when I did not get time.

In the Old School Assembly they have been having a great time. That Assembly you know last year delivered itself very decidedly against rebel sympathizers and required the churches to do so. The Presbytery of Louisville refused & protested very contumaciously under the lead of of the Old Politician Sen. Wickcliffe & Rev. Stuart Robinson whose health has compelled him to live in Canada for some years. Here at the Meeting of Gen. Ass. O.S. appeared the Said Stuart Robinson the head & ? of the offending as Delegate
Completed

from Louisville. The Northern men at once proposed that they have no right to vote as members of the Assembly till the Ass. took action upon them and their Presbytery. The Northern Men elected Dr. Stanton of Chilicothe (Brother of Secry. of War Stanton) Moderator.
Saturday they had a great speech by Dr. Thomas of Ohio, against the Kentuckyians  Monday a great speech exceeding elegant eloquent & elaborately Rev. Dr. Boardman of Philadelphia which I heard myself. 
For their favor. And today Tuesday I expect it has been magnificently replied to b Hon. Sam. Galloway of Ohio. I would have given something to hear it. Galloway you remember was President of our last Ohio State S.S. Convention. He is now about the best stump speaker in the state, and most inimitally comic as well as pathetic upon occasion. I think he had a fair chance to show himself in reply to Dr. Boardman.

                                                                               Especially
                                                                                          Isaac
Completed

I do not know as I shall get any letters from you - how I want to! - but I shall keep writing to you - every day like enough till I do get letters from you.
This is Friday 18th 6 P.M. Quite a warm day too it has been. and the first since leaving home. It had been quite cool weather until today. Our northern men begin to sigh and complain of the heat. I am disposed to laugh at them and tell them to wait a few days. It will probably grow warmer & warmer every day, perhaps for a week.
I begin to foresee that I am going to get dreadfully tired of this high & mighty - Gen. Assembly. It bids fair to be shockingly dull. I could hardly believe what I heard a commissioner saying on the way here that Meetings of the General Assembly were more tiresome than those of Synods & Presbyteries, which I suffered on the very acme of dullness. But I do not know but I may find it so to my cost.
In the first place the Moderator appoints Standing Committees on a great variety of Subjects Committees of 10 or 15 each - so that every Commissioner  may have a place on one or two.
Then there are lots of Permanent Committees which make long reports to the Gen. Assembly, wh take up hours in the reading, these reports being read are referred to "Standing Committees, wh make other reports on these reports etc. etc.
Completed

this page should follow the page dated Monday May 21 '66 five pages before as it refers to a battle that took place near Iron Mountain
The Battle of Pilot Knob was on this rise. Just before the Pres.dtl Election - Sept. 1864 - The Rebels invaded Missouri, the mightiest raid ever started, it is supposed 20,000. Cavalry or even more. Under Gen. Sterling Price formerly Gov. of this State. In the Pilot Knob gap, a beautiful little Plain between Pilot Knob & Shepherd Mountain, he found a a little octagonal earthen fort, just about big enough to hold its little garrison of 600 men under Gen Tom Ewing of Ohio but well supplied with Artillery & Ammunition.
The Rebels tried all day long to carry the little Fort by Assault, losing it is affirmed four fold the whole no of the beseiged. In the Night Ewing finding Price had got 'a large force around him, between him & St Louise and cutting him off, quietly evacuated, withdrawing his little force, and escaping by a little mountain gap on the north side if Shepherd Mountain, right away from St Louis, faith a race for life succeeded in getting away and to the other or S.W. Pacific R.Rd.  Price destroyed the Iron Mountain RR burning all the bridges, but did not come into St Louis as it is thought he might, but went off throu the central part of the state, got whipped
Completed

variously and finally run off out of the State taking with him it is s'd 60,000 horses!
At that Election the state of Missouri voted for Abraham Lincoln.
[written over the typed script below]Very Assuredly
Isaac

Thurs. May 24th 1866  St. Louis, MO.

Very Dearest

 Have just returned from the Grand Excursion to the Iron Mountain and Pilot Knob. Have just got and read your letter of the 21sr I am exceeding sorry about Mrs. Furber coming and going without you. I thought at first I would start right off tomorrow morning for home direct; but upon reflection concluded it w'd be too late at that perhaps, besides that I ought to go to DuQuoin  However perhaps it will not make much difference, we will find some one going East to accompany you. I will stay my time out, and come home at my leisure. You get all ready to as to start any time you get a good chance: Then you can start whenever there is a chance, and take your time. I want you should have a good long summer to rest, recruit, and get fat & strong, lay in a stock of health & strength as they tell about, and as I am doing nowadays. Not worry and tire yourself visiting about at a thousand and one places all summer; but go there to George's. where you can have the whole benefit of the bracing sea air and just take your time for it, all summer. And I will try and arrange to come after you.

A great trip today; special train, 6 last Cars on the R.Rd Gen. Assembly 200 and about 100 citizens of St Louis. I wished greatly you were along (as the western folks say) many times, 87 Miles, starting at 7 A.M. Pilot Knob at 10. A great Iron Furnace by arrangement just ready for a blast ~( the running out of the melted Iron) which is quite a sight for one who has not seen it; and then the Climb up the Mountain which is just a big pile of solid Iron about 600 ft high; upon the ragged tops of which the picturesquely grouped party first sang America, then listened to sundry speeches of Welcome, and glorification, and description of surroundings, and of the battle ground in the plain below; then a prayer from the grand old Scotchman Dr. McCosh, singing etc. Then down the Mountain Pacific Dinner; and I guess there was food enough for a regiment of a thousand men. Visit the battle field & back to St Louis by 6 P.M.
The N.S. Assembly is expected to adjourn on Monday next I may possible go to DuQuoin on Saturday, probably not however till Monday. I do not mean to stay there more than a day or two.
Completed

I.S.M.

                               St. Louis
                               May 26 '66                      St. Louis Mo.
                                                                               May 26, 1866

Dearest

 I believe I have written to you about our excursion to the Iron Mountain. Today have been out, this afternoon while Assembly has to adjourn for the Sexton to prepare the Church for the Sabbath, to the celebrated Botanical Gardens of Henry Shaw. About the finest gardens, hot houses & grounds generally that I ever saw, got up, maintained, and thrown open to the public by a single wealthy man of the City.  It is the same man that was a party to a celebrated "Breach of Promise" case a year or two ago. A Miss Carstang recovered of him $100,000.00 for breach of promise.  But Shaw got a new trial and got rid of the whole, verdict in his favor.
Completed

I have written a long letter all about these great ecclesiastical proceedings &c. &c. to the respected and very reverend John N. Putnam of Yarmouth Maine.
I calculate now upon going over to Du Quoin Monday night or Tuesday morning, and get home the last of the week sometime.
The great event of the day today is the Appointment of a great Joint Committee of 9 ministers and 6 Elders from each Gen. Assembly to confer upon a Union of the two great denominations. So I suppose it may be considered an accepted fact that the reunion is to be though it may take a year or two to arrange and perfect the details.
Well I hope to get home sometime and will be glad thereof.

                 Most absolutely respectfully
                                       I.S. Metcalf
Completed

Isaac                                                                                          St Louis Missouri 
St. Louis May 26                                                                         Sat. Morn, May 26 '66
1866
My Nettie

I have got pretty much tired out of this Assembly business. I did some think of deserting today or last night and going over to Du Quoin to spend the Sabbath. But now guess I shall stick it out till Monday, or when ever the Assembly shall adjourn.

I got no letter from you since the two, but on yesterday one from Eliab to say that he was not going to be at Portsmouth at present. I did some think if he were there of calling upon him on my way home. So I shall just run over to Du Quoin, stay a few days and calculate to get home in course of the week. Business of the Gen. Assembly drags its slow length along. Old School still quarrel briskly over the Kentucky folks.
Weather warm and dry.

                      Sincerely
