Isaac

                June 20th 1866

Wed. Eve June 20th
"If I am bereaved, I am bereaved," the Patriarch said when two of his family were away. 'Doubly bereaved' I suppose that means. His bereavement was the lack of two out of twelve, or sixteen, or 70 rather, was it not? Now mine is if 2 out of 6. My it is almost equal to the "one little ewe lamb" of Nathan the Prophet in comparison.
However I guess we had better not worry and I guess you need not for us.
Great Dutch Assault & Battery case in my office all day, has kept me busy.
Eliab got home last night safe and well.
John Finn returned in good order and reported you fairly started in comfortable train from Cleveland.
Completed

Boys have done very well; Evidently tried to be good.
Little Folks done well also; Anna slight signs of lonesomeness without or for the lack of May: but both happy and good.
Boys came down between 6 & 7 and went into the fair. Quite a lot of folks, many nice things etc. etc.
About the best thing however was little Fanny Topliff seated in an immense shoe "with so many children she didn't know etc."
Very many inquiries for Mrs. Metcalf, Rev. L.A. Wilbur informed me that he expected to be absent 2 sabbaths to come, going on Friday to Crawfordsville to Commencement of his college.

                                                       Especially
                                                             Isaac
Completed

Isaac               Thurs, Eve. June 21, 1866
June 21, 1866
Dearest Nettie

I have just got home from the "Torpedo". To begin there was a heavy shower between 6 & 7. It stopped raining and looked bright in the west. 8 1/2 after the Children were all abed & asleep I though I would go down and see what there was.

In spite of the rain, the Hall was fully as full as comfortable in a warm evening. On one side, George & Martha Washington  in the person & Mr. & Mrs. Gates, dressed to perfection, and really looking it very well, Nelso & Anna Mills as Old Quaker and daughter, and etc. etc. with black servants as "Continental Tea Party."

On the Stage alternate Tableaux & Music. Scenes from Ivanhoe. page is torn at both sides ? Moody & Mrs. Bronson (Miss Cooley ? as Rebecca & Rowena, & Kazz as Athelstane ? Scenes from Hiawatha. Nelly ? Minnehaha & Dr. Cushing as that ?? etc.
Completed

Singing - greatly admired.
Northop, T.E. Perkins the Composer. S.S. men etc. and the two Gates girls for Quartett, with Miss Holbrook to play. Solos, by Perkins Nellie Vaughan of Cleveland & Lizzy Gates. etc. etc. etc. etc.
But - Enormous rain. Thunder and lightning most excessive and sever. and deluges of Rain almost.
I waded home in it about ten, without waiting to see the best part of the show, thinking Eliza & the children might be frightened. How all those women and children are going to get home I do not know. It seems to rain harder and harder this hour past.
Children very good. John wants to go to the gate to look for Mama some.  page torn on both sides ? went down to Mrs. Curtis's ? Bundle, Bill $4.00 Carried ? another bundle.

? you are nicely sleeping in ? ? very tired, I am anxious to hear.
                                                    Isaac
Completed

Elyria, Lorain Co. Ohio
                                                                                                  Sat. Eve. June 23, 1866

[right-hand upper corner] Isaac June 23 1866

 My Dearest Nettie
  Your letter of Thursday Eve came to hand to night to our great satisfaction. I had heard from you before, Mr. Finn getting a letter this forenoon written at Schenectady, telling of yr safe passing there, and of May's being sick. I am suspicious that it was occasioned merely by riding backwards, in the cars.

I ought to have thought of it when you got in the cars. Perhaps simply the riding backwards from here to Cleveland might have disturbed the stomach, and she did not get over it all day; while if she had started right she might not have suffered. I am afraid you were too tired and ought to have staid in Boston, and rested a day. Am quite anxious to hear of yr safe arrival at Yarmouth. I mailed a letter Thursday Morning, and another Friday Morning, and hope you have got the first one tonight, but probably you will not until Monday. Wish I could look in at the Parsonage and see you this evening. You need not have been a bit afraid of May's being sick in the night. She probably slept all the better for the sickness, and it will not hurt her a bit.
I wrote you of the "Festival", I think. I have not yet heard the results. But it was a frightful storm that eve. About the greatest storm, thundershower - ever known here. And to night is another one somewhat most like it. It is exceedingly wet here I assure you.
Completed

Now I think of it, If you should happen to see Rev. Mr. Putnam Pastor of the first church in Yarmouth, or Old Dr. Burbank, or any gentleman who would be likely to know, I wish you would enquire when is "Commencement" at Bowdain College, which,  according to the maps, is in your vicinity, and whose festivals they may know something of by reputation at least.

 School Election here today, resulted in the choice by quite a majority of Henry E. Mussey and P.W. Sampsel over I.S. Metcalf & E.C. Griswold. Great Democratic Victory!

Very shrewdly managed by the Dem. leaders who are getting the Irish etc. in fine training for the September State Election. Election was from 10 to 2 oclock. Not a word of opposition, no demonstrations & ordinary light vote then, till half past 1, when about 90 Irish etc almost the full strength of the Democratic Party began to come in and vote in solid phalanx, Bill Whalan; Jim Wogan, Pat Cullin and all. Decent men mainly were at their dinners, and it was too late, (Polls necessarily closing at 2) to make a rally. The result is quite a relief to me. I did not feel at liberty to refuse to serve, while it is a tax any one may well rejoice to be rid of, And to be defeated in that way is really more of an honor than to be elected by an ordinary light vote. I was  pleased at one thing, when Irish began to come in, Judge Burke happened to be in the court house, and came in and voted right saying, "Why I wanted to vote against Metcalf on that school government question, but I certainly can't today."
Sabbath 
You may put your mind very much at rest about the children. The all appear to get along as nicely as can be. Little John is as happy as a bird all day long, occasionally wants to pull some one out to the gate to see if "Mama" is coming: but does not cry or grieve at all. He is exceeding good nights, hardly
Completed

wakes at all till morning, when he climbs up to play with me a spell, and tease to be dressed to run about.
Little Anna sleeps with Eliza, and is as good as a kitten all day long. The boys too evidently try to be good.
Eliab & his whole family went to the Lake yesterday, Saturday, upon a pleasure excursion, and I suppose got caught in the great shower. I haven't seen them, but I heard of them as coming through town in the rain. Eliab you know got home the night before you left.
Did I write you of Mr. Wilbur's going away, to Wabash College to be gone two weeks or so. Rev. Mr. Leonard  (French Leonard) preached for him today upon the glorious hope of the gospel. I was told the singing was very good, though Mrs. Carey was not there.
Festival receipts $660.00, Net almost $500.00 I believe the expected to bet $150.00! What shall they do with it? Lots of the Ladies are sick as the results of the festival, or of the getting home from it. Nellie Hall is quite sick. By the way I hardly know how very handsome Nellie is till I saw her in Tableau as Minnehaha. Mrs. Carey sick, Mrs. Wooster sick. Many others sick of Festival. Charles Ely sick.  I must tell you of a Mystery. There came a day or two ago by Express very plainly direct to Isaac Metcalf Elyria, a cane. Where did it come? From the Express Co. can learn only that it came from beyond Cleveland. It is Old, evidently been long used, but a very good substantial affair. correct for use, not fashion, heavy, ebony stick. ivory top well worn,  with a silver plate inscribed engraved "Presented by J.C. Pratt, Boston." No clue to whence or why it comes to me. Was n't "J.C. Pratt" Mayor of Boston for several years. Another yesterday came a California Newspaper, "Sacramento Union." from H.C.S." And who H.C.S. is I am sure I do not know, do you?
We have plenty of strawberries and green peas nowadays.
Please write very frequently and fully. May is going to write too. Sincerely ISM
Completed

You need not worry in the least about the Children. We are all getting extra first rate, so, far at least. The only trouble I have experienced of any sort, is Mrs. Twiss teasing whenever I see her for one of my children. However I guess I can manage to put her off.
Joseph Rich is not very well..
Very many people enquire for you, and rejoice that I have heard from you.
Completed

Isaac June 27 1866                                       Elyria, June 27, 1866
Dearest

 Your letter, the first, from Yarmouth, written Sunday perhaps, has just come to hand tonight, to our great joy.

It was anxiously expected yesterday, to say nothing of the day before.
I expect you were pretty thoroughly tired out when you got there. I am every day anxious to hear how you are getting along, you and May both, how your health and strength improve and increase.
I do not think you had better try to go to Dunbarton or any where else to visit till you get a little stronger and smarter. So as not to get tired out with a day's journey.
Just get rested, strong & healthy, for the first thing. And be under no sort of uneasiness about us or any
Completed

thing here. Every thing goes on like Clock work. I judge that Eliza manages the work first rate. Every thing seems to be done first rate. The Boys are very good about helping her to take care of John. Little Anna is good as pie all the time; keeps entirely still while John has a long sleep every forenoon. Never seems to cry, except when she thinks that John abuses her, which is certainly the case sometimes. John is happy as bird all day long, and really seems nowadays to be "taking to" his father considerable of his brother Wilder, & Charley too. He sleeps very well nights, and so does Anna.
He tumbled out of bed once in the night, and once I caught him by the foot after he fell off before he struck the floor! Moreover
Completed

he fell off the Veranday once, while trying to show Anna where his little Ball had fallen. I think that covers the Chapter of Accidents. None of them serious.
I dont believe you get so many strawberries yet as we do. I get two full strawberry season this year. We have lots, and great lots of peas also/
I do not know as there is any news to write. The Festival receipts were $660.00; Net about $550.00, so they say. I paid $2.50 for your Doll. And $5.00 for sundries, principally Ice Cream for school Marms, and Old Women who would not get it without, and the children's things- candy, cakes etc.
Completed

You had got my first letter when you wrote. I mailed one Thurs 21 one Friday 22 and one Monday 25; this will go Thurs 28th I intend.
I hope you will write very frequently. I wrote you of Eliab's ride to the Lake on Sat. 23d. Eliab has been most sick since he got home part of the time. Yesterday Tues. 26th, they had company Dr's Folks, and the H. & H. D. Halls. I was invited, but did not proceed.
Great Circus and attendant crowds in Elyria on Monday 25th, Another one next week.
I am much obliged to my dear little girl May, for her letter and will write to her specially soon.

                                     Sincerely
                                                    Isaac

Very warm weather here for some days until today. John broken out with heat some, but does not mind it.
Completed

Isaac July 1 1866

                                                                                            July 1st 1866
                                                                                            Sabbath Eve

Very Dear Nettie

We were largely disappointed not to get another letter from you by Saturday night. Have received but two from you one written from Boston and one from Yarmouth. I have written four times before this. And rather calculated not to write again until hearing from you again; but cannot quite resist the inclination tonight. Preaching today by the Rev. Mr. Kenyon (I think the name is) quite a young man, from perhaps Newark N.J. who married his wife in this country, and probably may be considered a 'Candidate' Appears to be very much liked as a preacher.

Great singing today. Lissy & Lottie Gates in the Choir with Mrs. Carey & Mrs. Briggs. Also Prof. Perkins the music publisher & singing Book manufacturer. He may be an especial admirer of Miss Gates. Emma Wooster got home nearly as straight as she used to be crooked.
Mrs. Sheldon here also and a very lovely looking lady she is too. Nelly Hall still quite sick a bed.
Completed

Little John, the small darling, was sick and almost frightened us this morning early. Wilder was drawing him about the garden in Carriage yesterday supper time or just before. Wilder stopped at a Currant bush to eat; the carriage & John happened to be under another currant bush, whereupon the Don John did help himself Ad libitum. But he got rid of the trash and seems as bright and well as ever this P.M.
It is greatly hoped that you will write frequently, at least, and we will try to so the same.

                                                                  Especially
                                                                          Isaac
Completed

Isaac July 2 1866                                        Monday P.M. July 2d 1866.
Dearest

  Your letter of the 28th & 29th Ult. I have just got hold of. The letter I wrote to you yesterday forgot to go to the Post Office this morning, on account of my morning nap. So I will write a bit more and enclose therewith. 

So you were at Bath last week. I am glad & saw there you knew there I suppose I would know a good many of the older clergy of the state even yet.
You do not write any thing about your state of health. I am hoping that the sea air, exercise, and freedom from care will make you grow strong and fat. How does May gain in flesh and color in her cheeks? Do you want to come home in Aug. Sept. or Oct?
Completed

This Forenoon, worked pretty busily in the garden with the boys in company. Little John & Anna also on hand running about or sitting in little Carriage.
After dinner I came down Town leaving Boys taking care of Children while Eliza finishes washing.
Eliab has been most sick with Diarhea since you went away, but says now he is fully well.
All the rest of folks are well as usual.

                                                              Sincerely
                                                                  Isaac.
Completed

Wed. Eve July 4, 1866

Isaac 
July 4, 1866
Dearest

  Must write you a bit tonight of our great occasion. The Boys you know had been promised an excursion to the Lake - sometime. The Livery Stable men had turned over a new leaf, or got a new wrinkle, and refused to let their horses to rowdies on such occasions, for extortionate prices. So decent people could get Team at somewhat usual prices. Mr. Boyd you know has moved down to his place at Avon Point, and got tolerably fixed up there. So he urgently invited Mr. Nelson, Eliab & Myself to bring our children down there for the 4th, And we went.

Mr. Nelson, with Kate & Anna and the three children E.W. with Maria & Hattie and 4 children.
Self & children & Percy, including John, & Eliza to care for him.
Boyd had got quite a nice place fixed up there, not much of a house, but in a nice place on the lake shore. Go down to get there through French Creek and Avon Centre, past where (I guess you remember going there), where the Stouders live.
Completed
Completed

Boston Buggy. But the break was not very bad and he got home with it.
Mr. Nelson, who was the unfortunate one generally, forgot to take out his teeth when he went in swimming, there came a big wave splashing over him,  throwing some water in his mouth, and opening his mouth suddenly to let out the water, out came the teeth also, and were seen no more!
Thereupon and thereafter the poor man did look and talk - well - horribly.
Every thing else went off admirably and entirely satisfactorily. The children came home very good naturedly tired, and are now all very fast asleep. The only drawback was that we found no letter, as every one there said, and we felt, that you were not there with us.
Hope we will write particularly how you and May get along, how your health is etc. etc. etc.
And write often.

                                            Especially Isaac
Completed

Elyria July 6 1866

Isaac
July 6 1866
Nettie Dearest
I mailed a letter to you yesterday giving an account of our Fourth of July at the Lake.
Last night came your letter of Sunday & Monday July 1st & Second, whereof we were glad. Little Anna shouts in great glee over her little letter from May, and John is always ready to join in with her.
I went into the old Yarmouth Church when I was there, although not on the Sabbath, so I did not see it 'clothed' with the audience.
I am sorry you do not enjoy your 'rest.' You must try to do so - for the profit - benefit of it, may perhaps depend in some measure upon your enjoyment or enjoying it. If yr "Occupations' gone" : you must wish to yourself another of enjoying the lack of occupation. 
The 'weight' you speak of upon your spirits must have been a 'premonition', I guess, if the burning up of Portland; which came the next day did it not? Did you see the fire I wonder from Yarmouth.
You think you 'ought to be doing some good', Of course you ought every day of your life. At home you have
Completed

have a great and constant good week - none more so - on your hands all the time. This Summer while away from home you have much good to do in rewinning your health and strength for your usual good doing. I hope you will be careful of May's reading too constantly especially of stories - and of eating too much of cakes and candies.  You speak of delightful matter. I do not know but it is here. But it is very wet, great rains, or very heavy showers follow each other almost every day. Tuesday might was a very great rain, Wednesday night a little one, and now Friday O.M. 6th, in a very heavy shower. Weather is quite warm withal. Strawberries are gone. Raspberries in full force. Green Peas abundant and likely to be all Summer
New Potatoes large enough - but we do not use them yet. You write of my coming East after you. You haven't yet replied to my question of whether you wanted me to come in Aug. Sept. or Oct. Really to look at it, it hardly seems as if I could go at all. What can I do with the children if I go. It is considerable to leave to any body's care. Eliza has not yet made currant Jelly. She has canned lots of Gooseberries.
The things you speak of I will try to bring (if) I come.
Completed

Sabbath July 8, 1866 Elyria

Isaac July 8, 1866
Dearest

 I did not get any letter from you yesterday nor did I mail this letter which I had written ready to send. It still continues very wet and rainy here. Great rain on Friday afternoon and night, and another of the same sort Saturday afternoon and night. We are all in good health and strength, all eating full rations. I think, in spite of so warm and wet weather.

A letter from Mary Barber came yesterday, wh I will perhaps mail with this to you.
Mr. Wilbur preached today upon the Love of God. Communion. Anna Maud Penfield baptized.
Allie Crane, and Miss Clark ( Lorenzo Clark's daughter of Carlisle Centre), admitted to the Church, with Mrs. Homan, Mrs. Washburn's Mother, by letter fm Buffalo.
Brought home yesterday five Photographs of Mother framed price $30.00. Charles carried one home this Afternoon. Yesterday was Circus day in Elyria, and crowds of People in town. Irving & Percy spent the day mostly here.
Completed

I have written to Mary Barber telling her that your being away need make no difference about her coming here in her vacation, of most for her convenience to do so.
Declining to advise her about going to Troy, as I do not know the people there.
What a terrible Fire at Portland, and all from boys fire crackers. I suppose you might have seen the light, and perhaps felt the smoke of it. And perhaps see the fugitives from it.
I wish you would write very frequently, and fully, and we will try to do the same.
Monthly Concert this Evening, few there on acc't of the Rain. It has not rained very much today but very constant threatening. Last night was great rain, and it looks as if it might be re repeated tonight.
Nellie Hall who has been quite sick has got about again. No one else sick that I think if, except Joseph Rich who is not very well though about. 

                                                                                   Please write often.
                                                                                       Sincerely
                                                                                                  Isaac

Little Anna says she "must write to Sister May" It would amuse you to see Little John get in the closet and hug & kiss your old Dress which hangs there.}
Completed

Isaac July 10 1866

                                                                                               Elyria July 10 '66

Dearest

 Your letter of the 5th inst. came to hand last night. Glad to hear from you. Sorry to hear father is not well. Glad if you & May are doing well.

We are all in fine condition. Little John is lively as a cricket and happy as a bird. Little Anna is apparently thoroughly well. I have been afraid she would make herself sick eating so many currants. But they seem to agree first rate with her. She will eat of them whenever she pleases.
Completed

She is just about no trouble at all any time.
The Boys are apparently trying to do well this vacation, and are doing so. Yesterday they picked 20 qts of currants, and today Eliza is making Jelly. Some of the currants they carried to Mrs. Topliff who wanted what we could spare. Eliza does first rate as far as I can see.
The children appear to be always well dressed, clean and whole. 
Eliza was homesick or lonesome I guess when you first went away but has got over it I guess.
She is making Jelly today.
Charles & Charley are here today haying and cutting wheat etc.
Completed

I hope you will write often & fully.
I want to know whether you and May are really improving in health and strength.
I told Eliza the other day that perhaps I would take Little John with me and go East. after you. And it troubled her exceedingly. She thought we were unwilling to trust him with her alone.
When do you want to come home.

                                      Especially
                                              Isaac
Completed

Isaac July 11 1866                           Elyria July 11 '66
Dearest.

 I have no letter from you to reply to tonight - but have a newspaper Copy of the Portland Press of July 7 containing acc'ts of Great fire.

Much obliged to you therefor.
Have mailed two letter to you this week, but one mailed yesterday, I found in the P.O. Box this Morning, it having been directed "Elyria O." instead of "Yarmouth Me." Lawyers W.W. Boynton & J.C. Hale leave town tomorrow morning for Down East. I do not know though as they will go any farther than Boston. Mrs. Boynton I judge goes too, Mrs. Hale perhaps is East already. Mrs. & Mr. Twiss just now called enquiring for Little Anna.
Completed

The Children are all very well.  Little John as merry as a Lark all day, and sleeps first rate nights.  Little Anna ditto in her quiet way.  Wilder & Charley are very good boys. Eliza certainly does first rate. Everything appears to be in good order and condition in & about the house. Children whole and clean. I notice that she sits mending boys clothes a good deal. Though I guess vacations is no harder for such things than school.   Eugene Mussey is sort of sick. I believe they think for going in to the river so much  Wilder went over and sat with him a spell this afternoon. He is "Afflicted with sore boils." Mr Mills & Old Corps Board of Teachers mostly are re employed in spite of opposition of New comers.  Eliab has been laying down Stone Walks went to Berea and got the stone.  Alfred Stevens has gone to Iowa to a good place secured for him by Miss Green.  Contest between Washburn & Doolittle for Probate Judge waxes quite warm.   Perhaps I wrote you about my caning. Miss Russel Kittredge's cane, it appears.  Perhaps I may add to this tomorrow.   Isaac
Completed

Isaac  July 12 1866

 Elyria  July 12 1866

My Dearest   Your letter of 7-9th inst came to hand tonight. I wrote to you last night but did not send the letter, thinking I would wait for today's mail, as there was one letter already in the Post Office to go today.  We are still all in very comfortable circumstances here, although it is very hot weather. At least so they say down town and every where else.  The hot weather does not seem to trouble me any. In fact I have hardly put on thin clothing till within
Completed

within a day or two past. Many seem excessively affected with the weather.   I do not think the children mind it much either. Anna wanders about in the hot sunshine sometimes with something on her head and sometimes without, and does not seem to mind it at all. The Boys have wit enough to prefer the shade I think. Little Don John we try to keep out of the hottest of the sunshine somewhat if possible.  I guess he has forgot all about you. At any rate he has got done going to the gate to look for, or calling for you. Some of us here think he is quite a
Completed

a nice little fellow.  I got today a couple of new and peculiarly striped palmetto.  - palmleaf hats for the boys. John 'Want for' one as the soldier boys say immediately, and took to it astonishingly. Utterly refused to have it off his head at the supper table - occasionally take it off him self to admire it, would not trust it out of his hands on any account. And absolutely insisted upon taking it to bed with him.   I have bought a new $15.00 Bureau for the boy's room with which they are well pleased.  They have been over to Mrs Twiss' today to carry papers.  Prayer Meeting tonight attended by several very languid looking people
Completed

very diligent withal - at least in the use of fans.  Glad to hear of your increased healthfullness. Be careful and not get tired & sick going to Dunbarton. Shall you take May with you to Dunbarton, or leave her at Yarmouth?  I really do not know what to do about going East. I hardly see how I can go away and leave these young ones. Suppose they should be sick any of them.  Relatives & friends are never to be trusted with children, are they? Even Anna, Little John went down there last week an hour or two, and they gave him cake or gingerbread or something, almost made him sick.  If I do go I doubt if I get there the 28th, more likely to start the 30th. But I really do not yet see hardly how to conclude to go at all.  What to you really think about it? - Is this the end of the Sheet?  Surely  Isaac
Completed

Isaac  July 15 1866

 Elyria, July 15th 1866

Very Dearest   Your letter of Wednesday 11th came to hand last night 14th.  Making three we received during the week: one on Monday which ought to have come Saturday perhaps; one in the Middle of the week and one at its close.  It seems that George is indispensable at Installations &c. But I presume the change in your arrangements is no very great trouble - to you at least. You can just as well go one time as another.   As for my going. I really do not know what to think. Sometimes - and perhaps that is most of the time, I think, that I certainly cannot go at all. It is exceeding warm weather;  By the way, today, yesterday, and the day before, are called about the hottest weather ever known here. The "heated term" is upon us in full force. People already begin to talk of '54. It is only just one week since it rained, and it is already a burning drough.  The hot weather "takes hold" of little folks you know: They are cross and restless and need somebody to take care of them.  I do not wish you were at home, I want you should stay there if possible through as long as the hot weather continues, I am afraid you and May would melt all away in this weather.  I most wish all the rest of the children were away in some cooler place.  Yet I suppose this
Completed

vicinity of the Lake Erie is cooler than almost any other place so far south as this.   The Children all seem to be strong & healthy. And yet in such extremely warm weather, if little children get hold of green fruit or cake or fat meat or any thing not easy of digestion they are sure to be half sick, and cross and restless. One day last week Little John and Anna got hold of & bit some green apples - the early Windfalls are beginning to get Mellow you know - and that night betwixt 'em they kept me awake about all night. However I do not know but they were just as well as ever by the next day. If I should go away, I do not know but there would be a quarrel about the children.  Mrs Twiss insists upon having Little Anna.  Elisa and Maria are like to quarrel about Little Don john. Elisa would feel terribly if if John should not be left with her; and Maria thinks he ought to come there. This hot weather make people stay at home here. Thursday evening meeting was but half attended, and today both Church and Sabbath School were very thin indeed   Mr Wilbur preached an excellent Sermon upon Christian Sloth, very valuable to young christians as well as to the rest of us.  But I am afraid no Children like May would understand much of it.   I do not know but I did about as well as Mr Wilbur.  You see last Sabbath there was a collection taken up to help purchase a new Sabbath School Library, which as Mr Wilbur introduced
Completed

the subject resulted in the magnificent collection of $9.84, mainly in dimes with a few coppers & quarters. I was dissatisfied and remonstrated, & proposed to try again. So today Mr. Wilbur called upon the Superintendent for Explanation. I got up and made a statement to the great congregation. Thereupon resulted a contribution of about $70.00 with over a dozen names to hear from left blank on the cards, including Ely & Nelson. Whole collection amount to about $100.00 I reckon. Upon the strength of that we donated some of our old books to a Sabbath School Mr. & Mrs. Boyd have started down on the Lake Shore in Avon.
Samuel Furber arrived yesterday. He will probably stop a few days I do not know how long. I guess likely he will call at Yarmouth on his way to Bangor. By the way he is coming back sometime in August probably. If I do not get there, you might return with him.
I really do not know what to think about it. I suppose you want to know when to expect me. I cannot tell. I do not think I will get away in July, or until the very last, say - if I go at all start Monday July 30th. If the children all seem doing well and the weather good for them I may start then. But do not be too confident of it. I may not come at all.
Perhaps we will let little Anna go over to Mr. Twiss' awhile this week to see how she gets along over there and whether Little John get along without her or is lonesome & fretting for her.
Completed

Would it not be the best way for you to make out your visit alone this year, stay as long as you like, if we are all well, perhaps come back with Samuel, when he comes - of if that does not suit, get George to come to Boston with you - you paying his fare - and frm there you could come alone well enough couldnt you? And I will make my visit alone next year. I shall want to be at Old Bowdoin at Commencement next year at any rate. Twenty years class meeting you know.
It is not just the thing to leave such a family as ours alone with any body a great while. Eliza is just as good, as any body could be, perfectly faithful & trustworthy; would take any pains or inconvenience whatever to do every thing just right and care for the children the best she knows. But after all I guess you would a little rather trust them with me here, and I know I should with you here. The best way after all is to travel enmasse the whole family, children & all. I think we shall eventually have to adopt that plan. When the children get a little bigger perhaps. What do you think of the whole matter? Call for the previous question?
I was going to send you some money in this letter. If you go to Pembroke Wednesday, this will not get to Yarmouth before you leave there. Perhaps I had better direct it to Pembroke.

                                                                            Especially
                                                                                    Isaac
